rawFindings.title: Technology Stack Disclosure
rawFindings.description: The X-Powered-By header reveals: "Next.js". This helps attackers target known framework vulnerabilities.

headers.content-security-policy: default-src 'self'; script-src 'self' 'nonce-MjUxNGM1M2MtY2JmYy00MjJjLWJhNDctYzRkNjk5OGZmMDE0' 'strict-dynamic'; style-src 'self' 'nonce-MjUxNGM1M2MtY2JmYy00MjJjLWJhNDctYzRkNjk5OGZmMDE0'; img-src 'self' data: https:; font-src 'self' data:; connect-src 'self' https://*.supabase.co https://*.supabase.in wss://*.supabase.co; frame-ancestors 'none'; base-uri 'self'; form-action 'self'; upgrade-insecure-requests

interpretedFindings.title: Information Disclosure via X-Powered-By Header
interpretedFindings.description: The application exposes its technology stack (Next.js) through the X-Powered-By HTTP response header. While not directly exploitable, this information aids attackers in reconnaissance by revealing the exact framework in use, allowing them to target known vulnerabilities specific to Next.js versions.
interpretedFindings.impact: Reduces attacker effort during reconnaissance phase. Attackers can quickly identify the framework and search for version-specific exploits, zero-days, or common misconfigurations. This is a defense-in-depth issue rather than a direct vulnerability.
reproductionSteps: Send any HTTP request to https://atmando-finance.vercel.app/login
Observe 'X-Powered-By: Next.js' header in the response
interpretedFindings.suggestedFix: Remove the X-Powered-By header by configuring Next.js to suppress it. Add a custom header configuration in next.config.js to explicitly remove this header from all responses.

topIssues: Remove X-Powered-By header to reduce information leakage (low priority, quick win)

recommendedChecks.name: cors
recommendedChecks.reason: Next.js applications often expose API routes with misconfigured CORS policies. Low cost, high value check even with no detected API routes - they may exist but weren't discovered.

recommendedChecks.name: traversal
recommendedChecks.reason: Next.js file-based routing and static file serving can be vulnerable to path traversal, especially in custom server configurations or API routes. Vercel deployment may expose build artifacts.

recommendedChecks.name: redirect
recommendedChecks.reason: Next.js applications commonly implement authentication flows and redirects. Even without detected redirect parameters, check common patterns like /login, /auth callbacks, and Next.js router redirects.

recommendedChecks.name: xss
recommendedChecks.reason: While no forms detected, Next.js apps use client-side routing and may have XSS in URL parameters, search functionality, or dynamic routes. React's JSX provides some protection but dangerouslySetInnerHTML and URL params remain vulnerable.

recommendedChecks.name: sqli
recommendedChecks.reason: No forms or obvious database interaction detected, but Next.js API routes may connect to databases. Lower priority due to no WAF and modern ORMs typically used, but worth checking API endpoints if discovered.

attackPlan.reasoning: This is a Next.js application on Vercel with no WAF detected and minimal surface area discovered (1 page, no forms/APIs). For a 'deep' profile, all checks are recommended but prioritized by likelihood of findings. CORS is highest priority due to common Next.js misconfigurations. Path traversal is second due to Next.js file structure exposure risks. Redirect checks target auth flows common in finance apps. XSS focuses on client-side vulnerabilities despite React protections. SQLi is lowest priority but included for completeness given the 'deep' profile and potential undiscovered API routes.

validatedFindings.reasoning: While Next.js does expose the X-Powered-By header by default, this is a legitimate but minor information disclosure issue. It's trivial for attackers to fingerprint Next.js through other means (/_next/ paths, React hydration patterns, etc.), so removing this header provides only marginal security benefit through obscurity. However, it's still a best practice to remove it via next.config.js (poweredByHeader: false) as part of defense in depth. The severity of 'low' is appropriate.
